ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 8: He is not really clear at all... His focus for lectures is to give foundational knowledge and then talk about questions that still exist in the field. Inherently this will leave lectures covering confusing conceptual material.Question 10: Graeme is unbelievably knowledgable! but he is dull and slow and confusing. but his knowledge is irreplaceable!Question 12: This course is very valuable! Graeme gets students thinking about the whole physiological picture of trees from birth to death. All MFs should take at least one course with him!

Question 1- on course materials, the syllabus mentions a HUGE number of readings and texts, which if all utilized and read would make this course a tremendous workload. Most of the concepts could be learned from the "Raven" textbook in addition to class summaries, maybe the others would be better listed as recommended readings or supplemental instead of becoming overwhelming. (and expensive)

Questions 1: The class was sometimes a bit difficult to follow, but the Raven textbook we used was very helpful for explaining the different concepts.Questions 5-7: I was not able to attend any of the field trips unfortunately.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Extremely knowledgeable prof. who is always willing to talk to students.
The instructor's experience and in-depth knowledge. He is able to answer many specific questions related to plant physiology.
I find that the content of the course, the subject matter is extremely valuable, basic knowledge to have, especially in forestry
I enjoyed the day in the lab when we looked at wood through the microscope. I would have liked to have had more days in the lab and in the Marsh Gardens.
A form of test is pretty useful to wrap up what I've learned in the class.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Students would benefit from labs that occur earlier in the semester.
The lectures often went over my head, or it was difficult to glean from the lectures what is important to know and what information is presented as supplemental knowledge.

The organization of the course could be improved. It was difficult to follow the syllabus and keep up with the reading. Also, the information taught in class was often difficult to follow and not explained very clearly.In addition, the course could have been improved by having more time in the field or in the lab in order to solidify the material we learned in class and in the textbook. It would have been great to visit the Marsh Gardens to examine different concepts. Also, more time in the lab looking at the structure of different wood would have been very interesting.
Lecture materials were a bit confusing to follow.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Possibly more actual microscope slides showing plant anatomy may be useful
Students would benefit from labs that occur earlier in the semester and with more guidance.
We did not have any discussion or lab sections.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: An essential component for learning about trees in the MF program.
This course fulfulls a requirement for the MF, and I think that understanding the underlying structures is valuable knowledge for forestry knowledge and management.
This course fits into my overall program because this is good background on tree growth and development which is useful to know for forestry and forest management.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: MF requirement, and I wanted to say that I have learned from Graeme Berlyn.
Expert prof.
It is a good refresher for overall plant physiology but at the same time allows for specialized focus according to interest.
See Question 17
I took this course to gain a stronger background about vascular plants at a cellular level so that I can better understand them at a macro level.
In order to study further about tree physiology

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes! I can answer the question "What is a tree" to more knowledge than previously& I am proud of my answer!
Yes.
Yes.
Yes
Yes it did meet my expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Bare through the dull lectures, do the reading from the Raven book, stop and think about what you're learning.
Be interested!
Have a specific learning objective you want to achieve for the course, i.e., a specific aspect of plant physiology you want to focus on.
Try to follow along with the course topics with chapters in the main textbook,and review summary material from lectures.

I would not recommend this class to another student unless they were very interested in cellular level biology and had some background in it already, because this class is very specific. If that is what they are looking for then it would be a great class for them.
This course covers pretty broad areas of trees, so students should be aware this and plan well before taking this course in order to improve the efficiency of studying.
